author: perama
content:
One use case for obtaining the full set:

Perform checkpoint sync and then characterise the ingress and egress of validators by iterating the set. If the proportion of exited validators was ever greater than one third, then you know an alternate chain can exist. This let's you determine if it was possible to have received a different checkpoint.

author: ajsutton
content: That seems a very strange use case and it will in time wind up always confirming that an alternate chain may exist. In reality an alternate chain may always exist because the checkpoint state you use may not have followed normal state transition rules (and you're not applying the historic blocks to check that).  So you always need to verify that the state you get is the correct one by checking against a trusted source (which may mean checking a bunch of partially-trusted sources to build up enough confidence).
